messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement Update
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-28T19:49:07Z
## Message ID: 20180328-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


This is an update to notification with ID 20180326-AL-002. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. The GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu on 2018-03-26T17:15Z and continues to be above this threshold, currently at 197,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-03-22T21:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-03-26T17:15:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 21, 2018 - March 27, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-28T19:16:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-03-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180328-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-03-23T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2018-03-23T18:00Z-24:00Z, 2018-03-25T00:00Z-06:00Z and 2018-03-25T21:00Z-24:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-03-22. The solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-03-27.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-03-25. Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-03-27.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-03-21T14:10Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACR at L1 around 2018-03-14 (see notification 20180321-AL-001). Later on, the threshold level of 10^5 pfu was crossed again starting at 2018-03-26T17:15Z and continued to be elevated for the rest of the reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes were then associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above that started on 2018-03-22 (see notifications 20180326-AL-001 and 20180326-AL-002). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:

Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  


## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-04-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one active region currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-03-29.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 14, 2018 - March 20, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-21T18:58:35Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-03-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180321-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-03-18T21:00Z-24:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-03-14 (see notifications 20180319-AL-001 and 20180319-AL-002). The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-03-19.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-03-15 and 2018-03-20, respectively. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-03-16 and again on 2018-03-20.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-03-16T18:10Z and continued to be elevated for the entire reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180316-AL-001, 20180316-AL-002 and 20180319-AL-004).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:

Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-03-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week with no significant active regions currently visible at the solar disk that could produce some flare or CME activity. An increase in geomagnetic activity is expected around 2018-03-24 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream. The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu again on 2018-03-21T14:10Z and is expected to remain elevated for the next few days (see notification 20180321-AL-001).


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-21T15:27:37Z
## Message ID: 20180321-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to notification with ID 20180316-AL-002. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded the threshold of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-03-16T18:10Z. The electron flux continued to cross this threshold, with the latest crossing at 2018-03-21T14:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-03-14T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-03-16T18:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-19T12:20:37Z
## Message ID: 20180319-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2018-03-18T21:00Z to 2018-03-19T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-03-14T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-03-18T21:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-16T18:43:13Z
## Message ID: 20180316-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-03-16T18:10Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-03-14T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-03-16T18:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 07, 2018 - March 13, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-14T21:55:48Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-03-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180314-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.   There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-03-09T21:00Z-24:00Z to 2018-03-10T00:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight increase of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-03-09T23:30Z of the S-type CME  (<500 km/s) event that started on 2018-03-05T23:39Z. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-03-20T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming reporting period.  There are no significant active regions visible on the solar surface.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2018-03-15.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 28, 2018 - March 06, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-03-07T21:09:51Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-03-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180307-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  An S-type (<500 km/s) CME was detected in the STEREO A coronagraph imagery starting at 2018-03-05T23:39Z.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that this CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth around 2018-03-10T00:00Z.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-03-03T21:00Z-24:00Z to 2018-03-04T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-03-03. Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2018-03-04.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-03-05.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-03-06. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-03-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one active region currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity.  A slight increase in geomagnetic activity may occur due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-03-08 followed possibly by the arrival of the flank impact of the CME mentioned above.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
